Author: jl777c#5810
Content: we are planning a KMD backed EUR stablecoin. so you would purchase 1BTC of KMD and deposit it, that allows to issue up to 80% worth of EURK, let us approx to 5000 EURK. these EURK are freely tradeable. you can use it on atomicDEX and once we get on a fiat exchange, can then deposit the EURK and then withdraw the EUR via SEPA.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: at anytime, you can payoff the 5000 EURK you issued and recover the KMD that was locked

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: there will be only be fees (tx, gateway, etc) but no interest rate you need to pay back

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: nobody is lending you the EURK, you are actually creating them yourself

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so it is a it different than all the other stablecoins as far as i know

yeah i had someone enquire about stablecoin marketmaking on this discord a few months ago.   they'll definitely pop up for stable 0.25 - 1.5% spreads.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the pegs CC implements a blockchain enforced decentralized stablecoin issuing. there will be ways for people to "mine" accounts in default and make 5%. to do this you will need to have EURK already, so it wouldnt be interest but rather liquidation fees that you can earn. personally i am not so fond of charging interests, the big problem is where do the funds for the interest come from. if we are dealing with a pegged value, we cant just issue more coins. which means people will need to pay it

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: anyway, there are plenty of such systems out there, EURK probably will be the only interest free loan system. this way, if you really need some EUR and dont want to sell any KMD, you can lock the KMD and borrow against it. as soon as you repay it, your KMD is released

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
As far as I know, in the real world you can always liquidate a loan that was taken against hard money (for example a savings account).

Many people will take loans because they think that the collateral will raise in value and they meanwhile wish to spend the loan in the real world...

What happens, for example, if the collateral has doubled or tripled in value but the borrower doesn't have anymore usdk to replay the loan? He is "stuck". I think that it's a useful use case to have a mechanism to "save" him. For example, a third party in a trustless manner could repay the loan in usdk just to get back the equivalent kmd plus a nice fee and the borrower could get the difference.

Author: polycryptoblog#1173
Content: @mobipoi   Why turn kmd to usdk : 1) hedging 2) fiat access without liquidating your kmd 3)  further pegging ( for derivatives ) .    When the value of KMD drops,  you will have to deposit more KMD and/or pay back usdk or else risk account being liquidated.  When accounts get liquidated 5% goes into a reserve for amelioration of debts and the liquidator makes 5%.   Debt holder loses 10% . In @artik123   Situation where price of collateral goes up the user either needs to acquire usdk from other users to redeem their collateral  or extract more usdk from account to cause liquidation to ‚Äúunstick‚Äù collateral and consequently sell the stablecoin on the open market for kmd

Content:
@polycryptoblog I know that this is what he can do, but I'm talking about the use case where he doesn't have the resources to to buy usdk to repay it. 
Think about the real world. You took a loan which was based on a (collateral) saving account (and the collateral is is all the money you have!), now you have spent the loan and you don't have money to repay it. You're stuck even if the collateral goes 10x.

Now lets say collateral kmd goes up 10x. How can I repay it? Even it you choose to issue more usdk (y) because the kmd price appreciate you still need to repay  x+y usdk to liquidate the loan

Author: artik123#2884
Content:
I would like to add a couple more words and sum up my thoughts.

There is a saying that the bank will give you an umbrella on a sunny day, but when the first drop of rain starts they will take it back. Some people get in trouble sometimes, and it's part if life.
Back to our issue. It doesn't always mean that when someone issued a loan he doesn't have the resources to repay it. It can also mean that at the time he wants to liquidate it he doesn't have them, and there is a big difference.

Regardless of what we spoke, I think that the "close account" option is in many cases a very convenient way to redeem a  loan. Even if he does have assets to redeem the loan, he wouldn't have to sell them in order to buy usdk to support the withdrawal (and then possibly to sell the kmd that they got to buy back the assets). It's just a hustle free option.

Without a "closing account" option, it could possibly lead to a systemic problem where, over time, more and more loans would never be redeemed and an ever-increasing amount of usdk will be floating around. I'm not sure what the consequences of it will be...

Author: Mylo#8306

10000KMD for initial loan of 5500USDK
You only have 5200 USDK to pay back, but have 4000 DGB.
Lock up the DGB, extract the value in USDK of say 300USDK.
Pay back the 5500 initial loan, unlock KMD.

Is this a suitable scenario for the close account with other assets?

Author: artik123#2884
Content: What happens when at the time you wish to liquidate the kmd your DGB has already depreciated to zero?

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
What if....
This is the risk of putting up collateral.  It is secured credit, not a credit card.
CDPs are used for loans to get liquidity for other opportunities with the hope of making the effort worthwhile.

If you have a mortgage to 90% of the value of your house, and the market goes down by 20%, the lending policy of your mortgagors (lenders) may be to foreclose on your loan.  It is the way secured credit works for lower interest.

In this case it is 0% loan.

In the event of DGB falling in value, it is unfortunate market conditions and whatever the initial 5500USDK loan was used for hopefully was used for good opportunities to outweigh the liquidation of the smaller asset.  If the market is screwed, what else is there to do?  Ask for a bailout?

Author: Mylo#8306
Content: I re read your question.  It is a market condition scenario.  The idea is to get a loan and pay it back quickly imo.  It is not designed as a multi year investment.....unless there is a huge bull market.
